prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Mira_b6
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Observations of Mira with long baselines in Band 6 Continuum but in (averaged) spectral line mode in order to remove molecular lines and use SiO masers for reference.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: The aim of the proposal is to observe the stellar continuum. However, as several molecules are found in the circumstellar envelope, we choose a FDM mode (with spectral averaging) in order to better remove line contamination. Additionally, there will be an SiO maser line that can (if needed) be used for self-calibration at the ~1.5 km/s resolution requested in the spw with the masers (the representative window has more channel averaging).

We request the longest ALMA baselines and the best angular resolution possible to resolve the stellar disc. We measured the disc to be ~43 mas and managed to uv-modelfit features approximately 10% of this at a resolution of ~30 mas. With the currently available baselines we will reach ~35 mas. This is sufficient to resolve the star again and with the increase in SNR detect mas scale surface features.
The limit of largest angular scale does not affect the observations, as both continuum and masers are significantly more compact.

From the ALMA SV observations in band 6 (Vlemmings et al. 2015), we had a continuum rms of 140 microJy/beam (using only 1 continuum spw) at about 30mas resolution. This allowed us to detect a ~5 mas hotspot on the stellar surface with a SNR~10 using uv-modelfitting. This was only possible because a high (~500 SNR) was reached after self-calibration. Here we aim to achieve at least an rms a factor of two time better (70 microJy/beam) than the SV observations. This will allow us to determine if weaker surface features are present.
At the same time, we will reach sufficient line sensitivity to image the masers wrt the stellar continuum.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: WHya_b6
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Observations of WHya with long baselines in Band 6 Continuum but in (averaged) spectral line mode in order to remove molecular lines and use SiO masers for reference.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: The aim of the proposal is to observe the stellar continuum. However, as several molecules are found in the circumstellar envelope, we choose a FDM mode (with spectral averaging) in order to better remove line contamination. Additionally, there will be an SiO maser line that can (if needed) be used for self-calibration at the ~1.5 km/s resolution requested in the relevant spw (though the representative window has more channel averaging).

We request the longest ALMA baselines and the best angular resolution possible to resolve the stellar disc. We estimate (from the radio) the disc to be ~70 mas. With the currently available baselines we will reach ~35 mas and thus can easily resolve the star and with the high SNR and uv-fitting detect mas scale surface features.
The limit of largest angular scale does not affect the observations, as both continuum and masers are significantly more compact.

Based on 43 GHz radio observations (Reid & Menten 1997) we expect W Hya to be resolved and have a flux of ~40 mJy/beam (35 mas beam). Similar to Mira, we aim for a SNR~1000 (after self-calibration) in order to detect small scale surface features down to the mJy level. As this is done through uv-fitting within the beam, a high SNR is essential.
The maser lines will be detected without problem (and can help the self-calibration).

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: R Dor_b6
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Observations of R Dor with long baselines in Band 6 Continuum but in (averaged) spectral line mode in order to remove molecular lines and use SiO masers for reference.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: The aim of the proposal is to observe the stellar continuum. However, as several molecules are found in the circumstellar envelope, we choose a FDM mode (with spectral averaging) in order to better remove line contamination. Additionally, there will be an SiO maser line that can (if needed) be used for self-calibration at the ~1.5 km/s resolution requested in the relevant spw (though the representative window has more channel averaging).

We request the longest ALMA baselines and the best angular resolution possible to resolve the stellar disc. We estimate (from the IR measurement of 57 mas) the disc to be ~75 mas. With the currently available baselines we will reach ~38 mas and thus can easily resolve the star and with the high SNR and uv-fitting detect mas scale surface features.
The limit of largest angular scale does not affect the observations, as both continuum and masers are significantly more compact.

Scaled from W Hya radio observations we expect R Dor to be resolved and have a flux of ~100 mJy/beam (38 mas beam). However, R Dor has no previous radio (or mm) detection of the stellar continuum. We thus conservatively aim for 60 microJy/beam rms and a SNR~1600 (after self-calibration) in order to detect small scale surface features down to the mJy level. As this is done through uv-fitting within the beam, a high SNR is essential.
The maser lines will be detected without problem (and can help the self-calibration).

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: R Leo_b6
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Observations of R Leo with long baselines in Band 6 Continuum but in (averaged) spectral line mode in order to remove molecular lines and use SiO masers for reference.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: The aim of the proposal is to observe the stellar continuum. However, as several molecules are found in the circumstellar envelope, we choose a FDM mode (with spectral averaging) in order to better remove line contamination. Additionally, there will be an SiO maser line that can (if needed) be used for self-calibration at the ~1.5 km/s resolution requested in the relevant spw (though the representative window has more channel averaging).

We request the longest ALMA baselines and the best angular resolution possible to resolve the stellar disc. We estimate (from the radio) the disc to be ~60x38 mas. With the currently available baselines we will reach ~37 mas and thus can easily resolve the star and with the high SNR and uv-fitting detect mas scale surface features.
The limit of largest angular scale does not affect the observations, as both continuum and masers are significantly more compact.

Based on 43 GHz radio observations (Reid & Menten 1997) we expect R Leo to be resolved and have a flux of ~45 mJy/beam (37 mas beam). Similar to Mira, we aim for a SNR~1000 (after self-calibration) in order to detect small scale surface features down to the mJy level. As this is done through uv-fitting within the beam, a high SNR is essential.
The maser lines will be detected without problem (and can help the self-calibration).

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Mira_b4
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Long baseline observations of Mira in Band 3.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: The aim of the proposal is to observe the stellar continuum. However, as several molecules are found in the circumstellar envelope, we choose a FDM mode (with spectral averaging) in order to better remove line contamination. Additionally, there will be an SiO maser line that can (if needed) be used for self-calibration at the ~2.6 km/s resolution requested in the first spectral window.

We request the longest ALMA baselines and the best angular resolution possible to resolve the stellar disc. We measured the disc to be ~35x42 mas by uv-modelfitting. With the currently available baselines we will reach ~62 mas. This is sufficient to resolve the star again and determine any structure changes and find compact hotspots.
The limit of largest angular scale does not affect the observations, as both continuum and masers are significantly more compact.

From the ALMA SV observations in band 3 (Vlemmings et al. 2015), we had a continuum rms of 40 microJy/beam at about 65mas resolution. This allowed us to resolve the elongated star using uv-modelfitting. This was only possible because a high (~800 SNR) was reached after self-calibration. Here we aim to achieve at least a SNR~1000 at band 4 (130 GHz). This will allow us to determine if structural changes in the stellar disc have occured (such as non-radial pulsations).
At the same time, we will reach sufficient line sensitivity to image the masers wrt the stellar continuum.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: W Hya_b4
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Long baseline observations of W Hya in Band 4.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: The aim of the proposal is to observe the stellar continuum. However, as several molecules are found in the circumstellar envelope, we choose a FDM mode (with spectral averaging) in order to better remove line contamination. Additionally, there will be an SiO maser line that can (if needed) be used for self-calibration at the ~2.6 km/s resolution requested in the first spectral window.

We request the longest ALMA baselines and the best angular resolution possible to resolve the stellar disc. The disc is estimated to be ~70x45 mas. With the currently available baselines we will reach ~59 mas. This is sufficient to resolve the star and determine any structure changes wrt the radio observations.
The limit of largest angular scale does not affect the observations, as both continuum and masers are significantly more compact.

The ALMA SV observations in band 3 of Mira, had a continuum rms of 40 microJy/beam at about 65mas resolution. This allowed us to resolve the elongated star using uv-modelfitting. This was only possible because a high (~800 SNR) was reached after self-calibration. Here we aim to achieve a SNR of ~1000, to accurately fit the shape of the star, which is highly elongated in the radio and resolve compact hotspots.
At the same time, we will reach sufficient line sensitivity to image the masers wrt the stellar continuum.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: R Dor_b4
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Long baseline observations of R Dor in Band 4.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: The aim of the proposal is to observe the stellar continuum. However, as several molecules are found in the circumstellar envelope, we choose a FDM mode (with spectral averaging) in order to better remove line contamination. Additionally, there will be an SiO maser line that can (if needed) be used for self-calibration at the ~2.6 km/s resolution requested in the first spectral window (the representative window has slightly more averaging).

We request the longest ALMA baselines and the best angular resolution possible to resolve the stellar disc. The disc is estimated to be ~75 mas. With the currently available baselines we will reach ~66 mas. This is easily sufficient to resolve the star and compact hotspots.
The limit of largest angular scale does not affect the observations, as both continuum and masers are significantly more compact.

The ALMA SV observations in band 3 of Mira, had a continuum rms of 40 microJy/beam at about 65mas resolution. This allowed us to resolve the elongated star using uv-modelfitting. This was only possible because a high SNR was reached after self-calibration. Here we aim to achieve a SNR of ~1600 in order to describe the structure of R Dor in detail. (Higher SNR is possible on R Dor considering its brightness, even in only a few minutes on source).
At the same time, we will reach sufficient line sensitivity to image the masers wrt the stellar continuum.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: R Leo_b4
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Long baseline observations of R Leo in Band 4.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: The aim of the proposal is to observe the stellar continuum. However, as several molecules are found in the circumstellar envelope, we choose a FDM mode (with spectral averaging) in order to better remove line contamination. Additionally, there will be an SiO maser line that can (if needed) be used for self-calibration at the ~2.6 km/s resolution requested in the first spectral window (the representative window has slightly more averaging).

We request the longest ALMA baselines and the best angular resolution possible to resolve the stellar disc. The disc is estimated to be ~60x38 mas. With the currently available baselines we will reach ~65 mas. This is sufficient to resolve the star and determine any structure changes wrt the radio observations.
The limit of largest angular scale does not affect the observations, as both continuum and masers are significantly more compact.

The ALMA SV observations in band 3 of Mira, had a continuum rms of 40 microJy/beam at about 65mas resolution. This allowed us to resolve the elongated star using uv-modelfitting. This was only possible because a high (~800 SNR) was reached after self-calibration. Here we aim to achieve a SNR of at least 750 to accurately fit the shape of the star, which is highly elongated in the radio and map its compact hotspots.
At the same time, we will reach sufficient line sensitivity to image the masers wrt the stellar continuum.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract:
Although processes like stellar activity and convection can have a major impact on the circumstellar chemistry and chemical yields of evolved stars, the surface and extended atmosphere studies of these stars have so far been limited to the visual to near-infrared wavelength ranges, or the marginal resolving power offered at radio wavelengths.
Using ALMA long baselines, we have recently uncovered a hot layer as well as a bright (likely magnetic) hotspot, on the stellar disk of the Asymptotic Giant Branch star Mira A (Vlemmings et al. 2015). This finding, contradicting standard model predictions, has demonstrated the unique capability to study the surface activity of AGB stars. It is now possible to map the stellar disk structure of four of the closest AGB stars. Here we propose observations in order to map and describe the emission properties of their extended atmospheres and determine the presence of stellar activity at unprecedented resolution. If the Mira results are confirmed and found to be widespread, it will revolutionize evolved star research by reintroducing the importance of chromospheric activity in e.g. wind driving, circumstellar chemistry and dust formation.
